commit_message:
Add support for data segments to SLO and SegmentedIterable

This patch updates the SLO middleware and SegmentedIterable to add
support for user-specified inlined-data segments. Such segments will
contain base64-encoded data to be added before/after an object-backed
segment within an SLO. To accommodate the potential extra data we
increase the default SLO maximum manifest size from 2MiB to 8MiB.
The default maximum number of segments remains 1000, but this will
only be enforced for object-backed segments.

This patch is a prerequisite for a future patch enabling the
download of large objects as tarballs. The TLO patch will be added
as a dependent patch later.

UpgradeImpact
=============
During a rolling upgrade, an updated proxy may write a manifest that
out-of-date proxies will not be able to read. This will resolve itself
once the upgrade completes on all nodes.

Change-Id: Ib8dc216a84d370e6da7d6b819af79582b671d699
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/71/365371/42 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2016 OpenStack Foundation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. """ Middleware that will provide Tar Large Object (TLO) support. This feature is very similar to Static Large Object (SLO) support in that it allows the user to upload many objects concurrently and afterwards download them as a single object. It is different in that it expects that the objects supplied in the manifest are meaningful individually, and that rather than the download simply being a concatenation of all the objects, instead you download a valid tarball containing all the specified objects. ---------------------- Uploading the Manifest ---------------------- After the user has uploaded the objects to be tarred, a manifest is uploaded. The request must be a PUT with the query parameter:: ?tar-manifest=put The body of this request will be an ordered list of object descriptions in JSON format. The data to be supplied for each sub-object is: =========== ======================================================== Key Description =========== ======================================================== name the path to the sub-object (not including account) /container/object_name etag the ETag given back when the object was PUT, or null bytes the size of the complete sub-object in bytes, or null =========== ======================================================== The format of the list will be: .. code:: [ { "name": "/cont/object", "etag": "etag of the object", "bytes": 10485760 }, ... ] The number of objects allowed is limited to a configurable amount, default 1000. On upload, the middleware will HEAD every object passed in to verify: 1. the object exists (i.e. the HEAD was successful); 2. ??? 3. if the user provided a non-null etag, the etag matches; and 4. if the user provided a non-null bytes, the bytes matches. Behind the scenes, on success, a JSON manifest generated from the user input is sent to object servers with an extra "X-Tar-Large-Object: True" header and a modified Content-Type. The items in this manifest will include the etag and bytes for each sub_object, regardless of whether the client specified them for verification. The parameter: swift_bytes=$total_size will be appended to the existing Content-Type, where total_size is the sum of all the included objects' bytes. This extra parameter will be hidden from the user. Slab file... ----------------------- Retrieving a Tar Object ----------------------- A GET request to the manifest object will return the concatenation of the objects from the manifest much like DLO. If any of the objects from the manifest are not found or their Etag/Content Length have changed since upload, the connection will drop. In this case a 409 Conflict will be logged in the proxy logs and the user will receive incomplete results. Note that this will be enforced regardless of whether the user perfomed per-sub-object validation during upload. The headers from this GET or HEAD request will return the metadata attached to the manifest object itself with some exceptions:: Content-Length: the total size of the TLO (the sum of the sizes of the objects in the manifest as well as the size of tar headers and padding) X-Tar-Large-Object: True Etag: the etag of the TLO (generated the same way as DLO) A GET request with the query parameter:: ?tar-manifest=get will return a transformed version of the original manifest, containing additional fields and different key names. A GET request with the query parameters:: ?tar-manifest=get&format=raw will return the contents of the manifest required to recreate the TLO. When the manifest object is uploaded you are more or less guaranteed that every object in the manifest exists and matched the specifications. However, there is nothing that prevents the user from breaking the TLO download by deleting/replacing a sub-object referenced in the manifest. It is left to the user to use caution in handling the objects. -------------- Deleting a TLO -------------- A DELETE request will just delete the manifest object itself. A DELETE with a query parameter:: ?tar-manifest=delete will delete all the objects referenced in the manifest and then the manifest itself. The failure response will be similar to the bulk delete middleware. ------------------------ Modifying a Large Object ------------------------ PUTs / POSTs will work as expected, PUTs will just overwrite the manifest object for example. ------------------ Container Listings ------------------ In a container listing the size listed for TLO manifest objects will be the total_size of the concatenated objects listed in the tar-manifest and the required tar headers/padding. The overall X-Container-Bytes-Used for the container (and subsequently for the account) will not reflect total_size of the manifest but the actual size of the JSON data stored. The reason for this somewhat confusing discrepancy is we want the container listing to reflect the size of the manifest object when it is downloaded. We do not, however, want to count the bytes-used in the container and account metadata twice for the manifest and the objects it is referring to, the header data stored separately, or the padding null bytes which are not stored. This keeps the container and account metadata accurate for stats purposes. """ import base64 import hashlib import itertools import json import mimetypes import re import six import tarfile import time from datetime import datetime from hashlib import md5 from six import BytesIO from six.moves import range from swift import gettext_ as _ from swift.common.exceptions import ListingIterError, SegmentError from swift.common.swob import ( Request, HTTPBadRequest, HTTPServerError, HTTPMethodNotAllowed, HTTPRequestEntityTooLarge, HTTPLengthRequired, HTTPOk, HTTPPreconditionFailed, HTTPException, HTTPNotFound, HTTPUnauthorized, HTTPConflict, HTTPRequestedRangeNotSatisfiable, Response ) from swift.common.utils import ( get_logger, config_true_value, get_valid_utf8_str, override_bytes_from_content_type, split_path, register_swift_info, RateLimitedIterator, quote, close_if_possible, closing_if_possible ) from swift.common.constraints import check_utf8, MAX_BUFFERED_SLO_SEGMENTS from swift.common.http import HTTP_NOT_FOUND, HTTP_UNAUTHORIZED, is_success from swift.common.wsgi import WSGIContext, make_subrequest from swift.common.middleware.bulk import ( get_response_body, ACCEPTABLE_FORMATS, Bulk ) DEFAULT_RATE_LIMIT_UNDER_SIZE = 1024**2 # 1 MiB DEFAULT_MAX_TAR_OBJECT_COUNT = 1000 DEFAULT_MAX_MANIFEST_SIZE = 1024**2 * 8 # 8 MiB MAX_BUFFERED_TLO_OBJECTS = MAX_BUFFERED_SLO_SEGMENTS REQUIRED_TLO_KEYS = set(['name']) OPTIONAL_TLO_KEYS = set(['etag', 'bytes', 'tar_name']) ALLOWED_TLO_KEYS = REQUIRED_TLO_KEYS | OPTIONAL_TLO_KEYS KNOWN_DIR_MARKERS = ( 'application/directory', # Preferred 'text/directory', # Historically relevant ) def parse_and_validate_input(req_body, req_path): """ Given a request body, parses it and returns a list of dictionaries. The output structure is nearly the same as the input structure, but it is not an exact copy. Given a valid input dictionary `d_in`, its corresponding output dictionary `d_out` will be as follows: * d_out['name'] == d_in['name'] * (optional) d_out['etag'] == d_in['etag'] * (optional) d_out['bytes'] == int(d_in['bytes']) where d_in['bytes'] can be a string ("12") or an integer (12). :raises: HTTPException on parse errors or semantic errors (e.g. bogus JSON structure, syntactically invalid ranges) :returns: a list of dictionaries on success """ try: parsed_data = json.loads(req_body) except ValueError: raise HTTPBadRequest("Manifest must be valid JSON.") if not isinstance(parsed_data, list): raise HTTPBadRequest("Manifest must be a list.") if not parsed_data: raise HTTPBadRequest("Manifest must not be empty.") # If we got here, req_path refers to an object, so this won't ever raise # ValueError. vrs, account, _junk = split_path(req_path, 3, 3, True) errors = [] cleaned_parsed_data = [] for obj_index, obj_dict in enumerate(parsed_data): if not isinstance(obj_dict, dict): errors.append("Index %d: not a JSON object" % obj_index) continue missing_keys = [k for k in REQUIRED_TLO_KEYS if k not in obj_dict] if missing_keys: errors.append( "Index %d: missing keys %s" % ( obj_index, ", ".join('"%s"' % (mk,) for mk in sorted(missing_keys)) ) ) continue # Filter out unnecessary keys so we can use manifest content directly obj_dict = {k: obj_dict[k] for k in obj_dict if k in ALLOWED_TLO_KEYS} # Handle object path obj_path = obj_dict.get('name') if not isinstance(obj_path, basestring): errors.append("Index %d: \"path\" must be a string" % obj_index) continue if '/' not in obj_path.strip('/'): errors.append( "Index %d: path does not refer to an object. Path must be of " "the form /container/object." % obj_index ) continue full_obj_path = '/'.join( ['', vrs, account, obj_dict['name'].lstrip('/')] ) if req_path == quote(full_obj_path): errors.append( "Index %d: manifest must not include itself as an object" % obj_index ) continue # Handle optional etag obj_etag = obj_dict.setdefault('etag') if obj_etag is not None and not isinstance(obj_etag, basestring): errors.append( "Index %d: \"etag\" must be a string" % obj_index ) continue # Handle optional size obj_size = obj_dict.setdefault('bytes') if obj_size is not None: try: obj_size = int(obj_size) obj_dict['bytes'] = obj_size except (TypeError, ValueError): errors.append("Index %d: invalid bytes specified" % obj_index) continue # Handle optional tar_name tar_path = obj_dict.setdefault('tar_name', obj_path.lstrip('/')) if not isinstance(tar_path, basestring): errors.append( "Index %d: \"tar_name\" must be a string" % obj_index ) continue cleaned_parsed_data.append(obj_dict) if errors: error_message = "\n".join(e for e in errors) raise HTTPBadRequest( error_message, headers={"Content-Type": "text/plain"} ) return cleaned_parsed_data class TarIterable(object): """ Iterable that returns the object contents for a TLO. :param req: original request object :param app: WSGI application from which objects will come :param listing_iter: iterable yielding the object objects to fetch, along with the byte sub-ranges to fetch, in the form of a tuple (object-path, first-byte, last-byte) or (object-path, None, None) to fetch the whole thing. :param max_get_time: maximum permitted duration of a GET request (seconds) :param logger: logger object :param swift_source: value of swift.source in subrequest environ (just for logging) :param ua_suffix: string to append to user-agent. :param name: name of manifest (used in logging only) :param response_body_length: optional response body length for the response being sent to the client. """ def __init__(self, req, app, listing_iter, max_get_time, logger, ua_suffix, swift_source, name='<not specified>', response_body_length=None): self.req = req self.app = app self.listing_iter = listing_iter self.max_get_time = max_get_time self.logger = logger self.ua_suffix = " " + ua_suffix self.swift_source = swift_source self.name = name self.response_body_length = response_body_length self.peeked_chunk = None self.app_iter = self._internal_iter() self.validated_first_object = False self.current_resp = None def _internal_iter(self): start_time = time.time() bytes_left = self.response_body_length try: for obj_dict, first_byte, last_byte in self.listing_iter: done = False obj_path = obj_dict['name'] obj_etag = obj_dict['etag'] obj_size = int(obj_dict['bytes']) tar_header_size = obj_dict['tar_header_size'] # tar_padding_size = obj_dict['tar_padding_size'] # Stop if we've exceeded our time limit if time.time() - start_time > self.max_get_time: raise SegmentError( 'ERROR: While processing manifest %s, ' 'max large object GET time of %ds exceeded' % (self.name, self.max_get_time) ) # Handle any bytes required from the tar header if first_byte < tar_header_size: first_header_byte = first_byte last_header_byte = min(last_byte, tar_header_size) if (last_header_byte - first_header_byte) > 0: header_contents = base64.b64decode( obj_dict['tar_header'] )[first_header_byte:last_header_byte] yield header_contents bytes_left -= len(header_contents) # Break the loop if we already have everything we need if last_byte <= tar_header_size: done = True # Handle bytes required from the object itself if not done and first_byte < (tar_header_size + obj_size): sub_obj_req = make_subrequest( self.req.environ, path=obj_path, method='GET', headers={ 'x-auth-token': self.req.headers.get( 'x-auth-token' ) }, agent=('%(orig)s ' + self.ua_suffix), swift_source=self.swift_source ) last_obj_byte = last_byte - tar_header_size if last_obj_byte > 0: first_obj_byte = max(0, first_byte - tar_header_size) last_obj_byte = min(last_obj_byte, obj_size) if first_obj_byte > 0 or last_obj_byte < obj_size: sub_obj_req.headers['Range'] = "bytes=%s-%s" % ( first_obj_byte, last_obj_byte ) self.current_resp = sub_obj_req.get_response(self.app) if not is_success(self.current_resp.status_int): close_if_possible(self.current_resp.app_iter) raise SegmentError( 'ERROR: While processing manifest %s, ' 'got %d while retrieving %s' % ( self.name, self.current_resp.status_int, obj_path ) ) # The content-length check is for security reasons. It # seems possible that an attacker could upload a >1MiB # object and then replace it with a much smaller object # with the same etag. They could then create a big # nested TLO that calls that object many times which # would hammer the object servers. If # this is a range request, don't check content-length # because it won't match. object_invalid = ( ( ( obj_etag and (self.current_resp.etag != obj_etag) ) or ( obj_size and ( self.current_resp.content_length != obj_size ) and not sub_obj_req.range ) ) ) if object_invalid: close_if_possible(self.current_resp.app_iter) raise SegmentError( 'Sub-Object no longer valid: ' '%(name)s etag: %(r_etag)s != %(s_etag)s or ' '%(r_size)s != %(s_size)s.' % { 'name': sub_obj_req.path, 'r_etag': self.current_resp.etag, 'r_size': self.current_resp.content_length, 's_etag': obj_etag, 's_size': obj_size } ) obj_hash = hashlib.md5() for chunk in self.current_resp.app_iter: obj_hash.update(chunk) if bytes_left is None: yield chunk elif bytes_left >= len(chunk): yield chunk bytes_left -= len(chunk) else: yield chunk[:bytes_left] bytes_left -= len(chunk) if self.current_resp is not None: close_if_possible(self.current_resp.app_iter) object_invalid = ( self.current_resp.etag and obj_hash.hexdigest() != self.current_resp.etag and first_obj_byte == 0 and last_obj_byte == obj_size - 1 ) if object_invalid: raise SegmentError( "Bad MD5 checksum in %(name)s for %(obj)s: " "headers had %(etag)s, but object MD5 was " "actually %(actual)s" % { 'obj': sub_obj_req.path, 'etag': self.current_resp.etag, 'name': self.name, 'actual': obj_hash.hexdigest() } ) # Break the loop if we already have everything we need if last_byte <= tar_header_size + obj_size: done = True # Handle any bytes required from the tar padding if not done and last_byte > (tar_header_size + obj_size): if first_byte > (tar_header_size + obj_size): num_pad_bytes = last_byte - first_byte else: num_pad_bytes = last_byte - ( tar_header_size + obj_size ) padding = num_pad_bytes * b'\x00' if padding: yield padding bytes_left -= len(padding) if bytes_left is None: yield 2 * 512 * b'\0' else: _n = min(2 * 512, bytes_left) yield _n * b'\0' bytes_left -= _n if bytes_left > 0: raise SegmentError( 'Not enough bytes (%s) for %s; closing connection' % (bytes_left, self.name) ) except (ListingIterError, SegmentError): self.logger.exception( _('ERROR: An error occurred while retrieving objects') ) raise def app_iter_range(self, *a, **kw): """ swob.Response will only respond with a 206 status in certain cases; one of those is if the body iterator responds to .app_iter_range(). However, this object (or really, its listing iter) is smart enough to handle the range stuff internally, so we just no-op this out for swob. """ return self def validate_first_object(self): """ Start fetching object data to ensure that the first sub-object is valid. This is to catch cases like "first sub-object is missing" or "first sub-object's etag doesn't match manifest". Note: this does not validate that you have any objects. A zero-object TLO is an error case - we do not allow empty tar creation. """ if self.validated_first_object: return try: self.peeked_chunk = next(self.app_iter) self.validated_first_object = True except StopIteration: raise SegmentError( "Could not validate TLO - manifest contains no objects" ) def __iter__(self): if self.peeked_chunk is not None: pc = self.peeked_chunk self.peeked_chunk = None return itertools.chain([pc], self.app_iter) else: return self.app_iter def close(self): """ Called when the client disconnect. Ensure that the connection to the backend server is closed. """ close_if_possible(self.app_iter) if self.current_resp is not None: close_if_possible(self.current_resp.app_iter) class TloPutContext(WSGIContext): def __init__(self, tlo, tlo_etag): super(TloPutContext, self).__init__(tlo.app) self.tlo_etag = '"%s"' % tlo_etag.hexdigest() def handle_tlo_put(self, req, start_response): app_resp = self._app_call(req.environ) for i in range(len(self._response_headers)): if self._response_headers[i][0].lower() == 'etag': self._response_headers[i] = ('Etag', self.tlo_etag) break start_response( self._response_status, self._response_headers, self._response_exc_info ) return app_resp class TloGetContext(WSGIContext): max_tlo_recursion_depth = 10 def __init__(self, tlo): self.tlo = tlo self.first_byte = None self.last_byte = None super(TloGetContext, self).__init__(tlo.app) def _fetch_tlo_sub_objects(self, req, version, acc, con, obj): """ Fetch the submanifest, parse it, and return it. Raise exception on failures. """ sub_req = make_subrequest( req.environ, path='/'.join(['', version, acc, con, obj]), method='GET', headers={'x-auth-token': req.headers.get('x-auth-token')}, agent='%(orig)s TLO MultipartGET', swift_source='TLO') sub_resp = sub_req.get_response(self.tlo.app) if not is_success(sub_resp.status_int): close_if_possible(sub_resp.app_iter) raise ListingIterError( 'ERROR: while fetching %s, GET of submanifest %s ' 'failed with status %d' % ( req.path, sub_req.path, sub_resp.status_int ) ) try: with closing_if_possible(sub_resp.app_iter): return json.loads(''.join(sub_resp.app_iter)) except ValueError as err: raise ListingIterError( 'ERROR: while fetching %s, JSON-decoding of submanifest %s ' 'failed with %s' % (req.path, sub_req.path, err) ) def _object_length(self, obj_dict): """ Returns the number of bytes that will be fetched from the specified sub-object on a plain GET request for this TLO (if performed as a sub-request). """ if config_true_value(obj_dict.get('sub_tlo')): return int(obj_dict['bytes']) - 2 * 512 else: return ( int(obj_dict['bytes']) + int(obj_dict['tar_header_size']) + int(obj_dict['tar_padding_size']) ) def _object_listing_iterator( self, req, version, account, objects, recursion_depth=1): for obj_dict in objects: if config_true_value(obj_dict.get('sub_tlo')): override_bytes_from_content_type( obj_dict, logger=self.tlo.logger ) # We handle the range stuff here so that we can be smart about # skipping unused sub-manifests. For example, if our first sub-object # is a sub-manifest referencing 50 MiB total, but start_byte falls in # the 51st MiB, then we can avoid fetching the first sub-manifest. # # If we were to make TarIterable handle all the range calculations, # we would be unable to make this optimization. if recursion_depth == 1: total_length = ( sum(self._object_length(obj) for obj in objects) + (2 * 512) # At the top level we must add the tar EOA marker ) else: total_length = sum(self._object_length(obj) for obj in objects) if self.first_byte is None: self.first_byte = 0 if self.last_byte is None: self.last_byte = total_length - 1 for obj_dict in objects: obj_length = self._object_length(obj_dict) if self.first_byte >= obj_length: # don't need any bytes from this sub-object self.first_byte -= obj_length self.last_byte -= obj_length continue if self.last_byte < 0: # no bytes are needed from this or any future sub-object break if config_true_value(obj_dict.get('sub_tlo')): # do this check here so that we can avoid fetching this last # manifest before raising the exception if recursion_depth >= self.max_tlo_recursion_depth: raise ListingIterError("Max recursion depth exceeded") sub_path = get_valid_utf8_str(obj_dict['name']) sub_cont, sub_obj = split_path(sub_path, 2, 2, True) sub_objects = self._fetch_tlo_sub_objects( req, version, account, sub_cont, sub_obj ) for sub_obj_dict, sb, eb in self._object_listing_iterator( req, version, account, sub_objects, recursion_depth=recursion_depth + 1): yield sub_obj_dict, sb, eb else: if isinstance(obj_dict['name'], six.text_type): obj_dict['name'] = obj_dict['name'].encode("utf-8") obj_dict['name'] = "/%s/%s/%s" % ( version, account, obj_dict['name'].lstrip('/') ) yield ( obj_dict, # TODO: # Because we're adding extra head/pad data to the output # we potentially need to modify the first/last byte data max(0, self.first_byte), min(obj_length, self.last_byte) ) self.first_byte -= obj_length self.last_byte -= obj_length def _need_to_refetch_manifest(self, req): """ Just because a response shows that an object is a TLO manifest does not mean that response's body contains the entire TLO manifest. If it doesn't, we need to make a second request to actually get the whole thing. Note: this assumes that X-Tar-Large-Object has already been found. """ if req.method == 'HEAD': return True response_status = int(self._response_status[:3]) # These are based on etag, and the TLO's etag is almost certainly not # the manifest object's etag. Still, it's highly likely that the # submitted If-None-Match won't match the manifest object's etag, so # we can avoid re-fetching the manifest if we got a successful # response. req_complete = ( (req.if_match or req.if_none_match) and not is_success(response_status) ) if req_complete: return True if req.range and response_status in (206, 416): content_range = '' for header, value in self._response_headers: if header.lower() == 'content-range': content_range = value break # e.g. Content-Range: bytes 0-14289/14290 match = re.match('bytes (\d)-(\d)/(\d)$', content_range) if not match: # Malformed or missing, so we don't know what we got. return True first_byte, last_byte, length = [int(x) for x in match.groups()] # If and only if we actually got back the full manifest body, then # we can avoid re-fetching the object. got_everything = (first_byte == 0 and last_byte == length - 1) return not got_everything return False def handle_tlo_get_or_head(self, req, start_response): """ Takes a request and a start_response callable and does the normal WSGI thing with them. Returns an iterator suitable for sending up the WSGI chain. :param req: swob.Request object; is a GET or HEAD request aimed at what may be a tar large object manifest (or may not). :param start_response: WSGI start_response callable """ resp_iter = self._app_call(req.environ) # make sure this response is for a tar large object manifest for header, value in self._response_headers: if (header.lower() == 'x-tar-large-object' and config_true_value(value)): break else: # Not a tar large object manifest. Just pass it through. start_response( self._response_status, self._response_headers, self._response_exc_info ) return resp_iter # Handle pass-through request for the manifest itself if req.params.get('tar-manifest') == 'get': new_headers = [] for header, value in self._response_headers: if header.lower() == 'content-type': new_headers.append( ('Content-Type', 'application/json; charset=utf-8') ) else: new_headers.append((header, value)) self._response_headers = new_headers start_response( self._response_status, self._response_headers, self._response_exc_info ) return resp_iter if self._need_to_refetch_manifest(req): req.environ['swift.non_client_disconnect'] = True close_if_possible(resp_iter) del req.environ['swift.non_client_disconnect'] get_req = make_subrequest( req.environ, method='GET', headers={'x-auth-token': req.headers.get('x-auth-token')}, agent='%(orig)s TLO MultipartGET', swift_source='TLO') resp_iter = self._app_call(get_req.environ) # Any Content-Range from a manifest is almost certainly wrong for the # full large object. resp_headers = [ (h, v) for h, v in self._response_headers if not h.lower() == 'content-range' ] response = self.get_or_head_response( req, resp_headers, resp_iter) return response(req.environ, start_response) def _get_manifest_read(self, resp_iter): with closing_if_possible(resp_iter): resp_body = ''.join(resp_iter) try: return json.loads(resp_body) except ValueError: return [] def get_or_head_response(self, req, resp_headers, resp_iter): objects = self._get_manifest_read(resp_iter) etag = md5() content_length = 0 for obj_dict in objects: etag.update(obj_dict['etag']) if config_true_value(obj_dict.get('sub_tlo')): override_bytes_from_content_type( obj_dict, logger=self.tlo.logger) # For sub_tlo do not count the EOA bytes # obj_dict['bytes'] -= 2 * 512 content_length += self._object_length(obj_dict) # The content length includes EOA marker content_length += 2 * 512 response_headers = [ (h, v) for h, v in resp_headers if h.lower() not in ('etag', 'content-length') ] response_headers.append(('Content-Length', str(content_length))) response_headers.append(('Etag', '"%s"' % etag.hexdigest())) if req.method == 'HEAD': return self._manifest_head_response(req, response_headers) else: return self._manifest_get_response( req, content_length, response_headers, objects ) def _manifest_head_response(self, req, response_headers): return HTTPOk(request=req, headers=response_headers, body='', conditional_response=True) def _manifest_get_response( self, req, content_length, response_headers, objects): self.first_byte, self.last_byte = None, None if req.range: byteranges = req.range.ranges_for_length(content_length) if len(byteranges) == 0: return HTTPRequestedRangeNotSatisfiable(request=req) elif len(byteranges) == 1: self.first_byte, self.last_byte = byteranges[0] else: req.range = None ver, account, _junk = req.split_path(3, 3, rest_with_last=True) plain_listing_iter = self._object_listing_iterator( req, ver, account, objects ) # TODO: Reintroduce when we upgrade to 2.7.x # # def is_small_object((obj_dict, start_byte, end_byte)): # start = 0 if start_byte is None else start_byte # end = int(obj_dict['bytes'])-1 if end_byte is None else end_byte # is_small = (end - start + 1) < self.tlo.rate_limit_under_size # return is_small ratelimited_listing_iter = RateLimitedIterator( plain_listing_iter, self.tlo.rate_limit_objects_per_sec, limit_after=self.tlo.rate_limit_after_object ) # Not supported by 2.2.x # ratelimit_if=is_small_object # ) if self.first_byte is not None and self.last_byte is not None: body_length = self.last_byte - self.first_byte else: body_length = content_length tar_iter = TarIterable( req, self.tlo.app, ratelimited_listing_iter, name=req.path, logger=self.tlo.logger, ua_suffix="TLO MultipartGET", swift_source="TLO", max_get_time=self.tlo.max_get_time, response_body_length=body_length ) try: tar_iter.validate_first_object() except (ListingIterError, SegmentError): # Copy from the TLO explanation in top of this file. # If any of the objects from the manifest are not found or # their Etag/Content Length no longer match the connection # will drop. In this case a 409 Conflict will be logged in # the proxy logs and the user will receive incomplete results. return HTTPConflict(request=req) response = Response( request=req, content_length=content_length, headers=response_headers, conditional_response=True, app_iter=tar_iter ) if req.range: response.headers.pop('Etag') return response def make_tar_extras(path, size, tar_type, last_modified): info = tarfile.TarInfo(name=path) info.mtime = last_modified info.size = size info.type = tar_type tar_header = info.tobuf(format=tarfile.GNU_FORMAT) padding_mod = size % tarfile.BLOCKSIZE if padding_mod > 0: padding_size = tarfile.BLOCKSIZE - padding_mod else: padding_size = 0 return(tar_header, padding_size) class TarLargeObject(object): """ TarLargeObject Middleware See above for a full description. The proxy logs created for any sub-requests made will have swift.source set to "TLO". :param app: The next WSGI filter or app in the paste.deploy chain. :param conf: The configuration dict for the middleware. """ def __init__(self, app, conf, max_manifest_objects=DEFAULT_MAX_TAR_OBJECT_COUNT, max_manifest_size=DEFAULT_MAX_MANIFEST_SIZE): self.conf = conf self.app = app self.logger = get_logger(conf, log_route='tlo') self.max_manifest_objects = max_manifest_objects self.max_manifest_size = max_manifest_size self.max_get_time = int(self.conf.get('max_get_time', 86400)) self.rate_limit_under_size = int(self.conf.get( 'rate_limit_under_size', DEFAULT_RATE_LIMIT_UNDER_SIZE)) self.rate_limit_after_object = int(self.conf.get( 'rate_limit_after_object', '10')) self.rate_limit_objects_per_sec = int(self.conf.get( 'rate_limit_objects_per_sec', '1')) self.bulk_deleter = Bulk( app, {}, logger=self.logger ) # TODO: Reintroduce when we upgrade to 2.7.x # # Not available in 2.2.x # delete_concurrency = int(self.conf.get('delete_concurrency', '2')) # self.bulk_deleter = Bulk( # app, {}, # delete_concurrency=delete_concurrency, logger=self.logger # ) def handle_multipart_get_or_head(self, req, start_response): """ Handles the GET or HEAD of a TLO manifest. The response body (only on GET, of course) will consist of the concatenation of the objects. :params req: a swob.Request with a path referencing an object :raises: HttpException on errors """ return TloGetContext(self).handle_tlo_get_or_head(req, start_response) def handle_multipart_put(self, req, start_response): """ Will handle the PUT of a TLO manifest. Heads every object in manifest to check if is valid and if so will save a manifest generated from the user input. Uses WSGIContext to call self and start_response and returns a WSGI iterator. :params req: a swob.Request with an obj in path :raises: HttpException on errors """ try: vrs, account, container, obj = req.split_path(1, 4, True) except ValueError: return self.app(req.environ, start_response) if req.content_length > self.max_manifest_size: raise HTTPRequestEntityTooLarge( "Manifest File > %d bytes" % self.max_manifest_size) if req.headers.get('X-Copy-From'): raise HTTPMethodNotAllowed( 'Multipart Manifest PUTs cannot be COPY requests') if req.content_length is None and \ req.headers.get('transfer-encoding', '').lower() != 'chunked': raise HTTPLengthRequired(request=req) parsed_data = parse_and_validate_input( req.body_file.read(self.max_manifest_size), req.path ) if len(parsed_data) > self.max_manifest_objects: raise HTTPRequestEntityTooLarge( 'Number of objects must be <= %d' % self.max_manifest_objects) total_size = 0 out_content_type = req.accept.best_match(ACCEPTABLE_FORMATS) if not out_content_type: out_content_type = 'text/plain' data_for_storage = [] problem_objects = [] tlo_etag = md5() for index, obj_dict in enumerate(parsed_data): problem = False obj_name = obj_dict['name'] tar_name = obj_dict.setdefault('tar_name', obj_name) if isinstance(obj_name, six.text_type): obj_name = obj_name.encode('utf-8') obj_path = '/'.join(['', vrs, account, obj_name.lstrip('/')]) sub_req = make_subrequest( req.environ, path=obj_path + '?', # kill the query string method='HEAD', headers={'x-auth-token': req.headers.get('x-auth-token')}, agent='%(orig)s TLO MultipartPUT', swift_source='TLO' ) head_obj_resp = sub_req.get_response(self) if head_obj_resp.is_success: obj_name = '/' + obj_dict['name'].lstrip('/') obj_size = obj_dict['bytes'] if head_obj_resp.content_length < 1: # Is this a dir marker or 0-byte file? dir_marker = any([ True for k in head_obj_resp.headers if k.lower() == 'content-type' and head_obj_resp.headers[k].lower() in KNOWN_DIR_MARKERS ]) if dir_marker: obj_type = tarfile.DIRTYPE else: obj_type = tarfile.REGTYPE else: obj_type = tarfile.REGTYPE incorrect_size = ( obj_size is not None and obj_size != int(head_obj_resp.content_length) ) if incorrect_size: problem_objects.append([quote(obj_name), 'Size Mismatch']) if obj_size is None: obj_size = int(head_obj_resp.content_length) incorrect_etag = ( obj_dict['etag'] is not None and obj_dict['etag'] != head_obj_resp.etag ) if incorrect_etag: problem_objects.append([quote(obj_name), 'Etag Mismatch']) problem = True else: tlo_etag.update(head_obj_resp.etag) # We've now listed all possible problems, so abort processing # this object if we found any if problem: continue if head_obj_resp.last_modified: # last_modified is always UTC last_modified = head_obj_resp.last_modified else: # shouldn't happen last_modified = datetime.utcnow() last_modified_formatted = last_modified.strftime( '%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S.%f' ) last_modified_epoch = time.mktime(last_modified.timetuple()) sub_tlo = config_true_value( head_obj_resp.headers.get('X-Tar-Large-Object') ) if sub_tlo: obj_data = { 'name': obj_name, # The byte count is 1024 bytes shorter for sub-tlo # because we must not include the EOA marker 'bytes': int(head_obj_resp.content_length) - (2 * 512), 'etag': head_obj_resp.etag, 'content_type': head_obj_resp.content_type, 'last_modified': last_modified_formatted, 'sub_tlo': sub_tlo } else: tar_name = obj_dict['tar_name'] tar_header, padding_size = make_tar_extras( tar_name, obj_size, obj_type, last_modified_epoch ) tar_header_size = len(tar_header) total_size += obj_size + tar_header_size + padding_size obj_data = { 'name': obj_name, 'bytes': head_obj_resp.content_length, 'etag': head_obj_resp.etag, 'content_type': head_obj_resp.content_type, 'last_modified': last_modified_formatted, 'sub_tlo': sub_tlo, 'tar_name': tar_name, 'tar_header': base64.b64encode(tar_header), 'tar_header_size': tar_header_size, 'tar_padding_size': padding_size } data_for_storage.append(obj_data) else: problem_objects.append( [quote(obj_name), head_obj_resp.status] ) if problem_objects: resp_body = get_response_body( out_content_type, {}, problem_objects) raise HTTPBadRequest(resp_body, content_type=out_content_type) # All objects were successfully checked, so continue env = req.environ if not env.get('CONTENT_TYPE'): guessed_type, _junk = mimetypes.guess_type(req.path_info) env['CONTENT_TYPE'] = guessed_type or 'application/octet-stream' env['swift.content_type_overridden'] = True env['CONTENT_TYPE'] += ";swift_bytes=%d" % total_size env['HTTP_X_TAR_LARGE_OBJECT'] = 'True' json_data = json.dumps(data_for_storage) if six.PY3: json_data = json_data.encode('utf-8') env['CONTENT_LENGTH'] = str(len(json_data)) env['wsgi.input'] = BytesIO(json_data) tlo_put_context = TloPutContext(self, tlo_etag) return tlo_put_context.handle_tlo_put(req, start_response) def get_objects_to_delete_iter(self, req): """ A generator function to be used to delete all the objects and sub-objects referenced in a manifest. :params req: a swob.Request with an TLO manifest in path :raises HTTPPreconditionFailed: on invalid UTF8 in request path :raises HTTPBadRequest: on too many buffered sub objects and on invalid TLO manifest path """ if not check_utf8(req.path_info): raise HTTPPreconditionFailed( request=req, body='Invalid UTF8 or contains NULL') vrs, account, container, obj = req.split_path(4, 4, True) objects = [{ 'sub_tlo': True, 'name': ('/%s/%s' % (container, obj)).decode('utf-8') }] while objects: if len(objects) > MAX_BUFFERED_TLO_OBJECTS: raise HTTPBadRequest( 'Too many buffered tlo objects to delete.') obj_data = objects.pop(0) if obj_data.get('sub_tlo'): try: objects.extend( self.get_tlo_objects(obj_data['name'], req)) except HTTPException as err: # allow bulk delete response to report errors obj_data['error'] = { 'code': err.status_int, 'message': err.body } # add manifest back to be deleted after objects obj_data['sub_tlo'] = False objects.append(obj_data) else: obj_data['name'] = obj_data['name'].encode('utf-8') yield obj_data def get_tlo_objects(self, obj_name, req): """ Performs a swob.Request and returns the TLO manifest's contents. :raises HTTPServerError: on unable to load obj_name or on unable to load the TLO manifest data. :raises HTTPBadRequest: on not an TLO manifest :raises HTTPNotFound: on TLO manifest not found :returns: TLO manifest's objects """ vrs, account, _junk = req.split_path(2, 3, True) new_env = req.environ.copy() new_env['REQUEST_METHOD'] = 'GET' del(new_env['wsgi.input']) new_env['QUERY_STRING'] = 'tar-manifest=get' new_env['CONTENT_LENGTH'] = 0 new_env['HTTP_USER_AGENT'] = \ '%s MultipartDELETE' % new_env.get('HTTP_USER_AGENT') new_env['swift.source'] = 'TLO' new_env['PATH_INFO'] = ( '/%s/%s/%s' % (vrs, account, obj_name.lstrip('/')) ).encode('utf-8') resp = Request.blank('', new_env).get_response(self.app) if resp.is_success: if config_true_value(resp.headers.get('X-Tar-Large-Object')): try: return json.loads(resp.body) except ValueError: raise HTTPServerError('Unable to load TLO manifest') else: raise HTTPBadRequest('Not an TLO manifest') elif resp.status_int == HTTP_NOT_FOUND: raise HTTPNotFound('TLO manifest not found') elif resp.status_int == HTTP_UNAUTHORIZED: raise HTTPUnauthorized('401 Unauthorized') else: raise HTTPServerError('Unable to load TLO manifest or object.') def handle_multipart_delete(self, req): """ Will delete all the objects in the TLO manifest and then, if successful, will delete the manifest file. :params req: a swob.Request with an obj in path :returns: swob.Response whose app_iter set to Bulk.handle_delete_iter """ req.headers['Content-Type'] = None # Ignore content-type from client resp = HTTPOk(request=req) out_content_type = req.accept.best_match(ACCEPTABLE_FORMATS) if out_content_type: resp.content_type = out_content_type resp.app_iter = self.bulk_deleter.handle_delete_iter( req, objs_to_delete=self.get_objects_to_delete_iter(req), user_agent='MultipartDELETE', swift_source='TLO', out_content_type=out_content_type) return resp def __call__(self, env, start_response): """ WSGI entry point """ req = Request(env) try: vrs, account, container, obj = req.split_path(4, 4, True) except ValueError: return self.app(env, start_response) try: if req.method == 'PUT' and \ req.params.get('tar-manifest') == 'put': return self.handle_multipart_put(req, start_response) if req.method == 'DELETE' and \ req.params.get('tar-manifest') == 'delete': return self.handle_multipart_delete(req)(env, start_response) if req.method == 'GET' or req.method == 'HEAD': return self.handle_multipart_get_or_head(req, start_response) if 'X-Tar-Large-Object' in req.headers: raise HTTPBadRequest( request=req, body='X-Tar-Large-Object is a reserved header. ' 'To create a tar large object add query param ' 'tar-manifest=put.') except HTTPException as err_resp: return err_resp(env, start_response) return self.app(env, start_response) def filter_factory(global_conf, **local_conf): conf = global_conf.copy() conf.update(local_conf) max_manifest_objects = int( conf.get('max_manifest_objects', DEFAULT_MAX_TAR_OBJECT_COUNT) ) max_manifest_size = int( conf.get('max_manifest_size', DEFAULT_MAX_MANIFEST_SIZE) ) register_swift_info( 'tlo', max_manifest_objects=max_manifest_objects, max_manifest_size=max_manifest_size, ) def tlo_filter(app): return TarLargeObject( app, conf, max_manifest_objects=max_manifest_objects, max_manifest_size=max_manifest_size) return tlo_filter

commit_message:
Fixing 'Create Alarm Definition' for IE11

The widget ngTags is used to select dimensions. This widget does not
work with IE 11 and the AngularJS versions provided by Horizon. Replacing
ng-click event with ng-mousedown event, because the ng-click event does
not fire on IE11 in the given dialog layout.

Change-Id: I9918debd164dce7ddc4bba15a07d6f3edddc7a09
Story: 2001504
Task: 6295
(cherry picked from commit 4c2cabb50b0b39621d0dda74f2ffb5120f825c1d)

commit_message:
Update Custom Profile field help/error messages

This contribution updates the inline help message as well as the
error message for the Custom Profile field to be more user friendly.
This field can be seen when the user chooses to tag a node with a
"Custom Profile".

Change-Id: I2a88a4fc5f58c7d61e981f1db2130e07e8054310
Closes-Bug: #1673526

commit_message:
Adds documentation

This patch adds basic details about:

* Supported OS versions
* Requirements and host configurations
* MSI installer, its features, and arguments
* Further steps after installing and configuring the
  nova-compute service
* Troubleshooting tips
* Usage

Change-Id: Icf7ba18121547ba7ea37fdefdb3c9510aeb1654e

commit_message:
Add password authentification in monasca-api with Cassandra

Add the support to configure user and password in monasca api and enforce
the authetification when connecting to cassandra db when the user and
password is set.

Change-Id: I9e6689e0e8e6e97d5cff3a59aecb53483ec320bd
story: 2001471
task: 6191

added_lines: # (C) Copyright 2017-2018 SUSE LLCfrom cassandra.auth import PlainTextAuthProvider if self.conf.cassandra.user: auth_provider = PlainTextAuthProvider(username=self.conf.cassandra.user, password=self.conf.cassandra.password) else: auth_provider = None self.cluster = Cluster(self.conf.cassandra.contact_points, auth_provider=auth_provider)

commit_message:
Deprecate classic drivers

Also address small issues in the release note for the migration
to hardware types.

Change-Id: I32998c5508e01882714a76751482a916d066f938
Partial-Bug: #1690185
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/28/536928/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- prelude: > This release deprecate classic drivers in favor of hardware types. Please check `the migration guide <https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/admin/upgrade-to-hardware-types.html>`_ for information on how to update your nodes. deprecations: - | The classic drivers, as well as the ``enabled_drivers`` option, are now deprecated. A deprecation warning will be issued for every loaded classic driver. Check `the migration guide <https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/admin/upgrade-to-hardware-types.html>`_ for information on how to update your nodes. Check `the specification <http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-specs/specs/approved/classic-drivers-future.html>`_ for technical information behind this deprecation.

commit_message:
Fix SELinux policy filenames

Within the SELinux policy file itself, the policy is referenced
as `osa-neutron`, but the filename for the policy did not match.
This patch fixes the filenames to match the policy name.

Closes-Bug: 1742552
Change-Id: I52901ac48f9a95d0fe6b010f5940b5c39fce1aba

commit_message:
Cover string representations of api_versions.APIVersion

Adding unit-tests to check string representation and repr()
results for api_versions.APIVersion instances.
Both for valid versions and null.

This increases code coverage.

Change-Id: I53125c0f993a54812d47341c7956222b7da65c7f
Partial-Bug: #1364800
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-manilaclient refs/changes/17/537317/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.assertEqual(repr(v), "<APIVersion: null>") @ddt.data("2.0", "2.5", "2.45", "3.3", "3.23", "2.0", "3.3", "4.0") def test_representation(self, version): version_major, version_minor = version.split('.') api_version = api_versions.APIVersion(version) self.assertEqual(str(api_version), ("API Version Major: %s, Minor: %s" % (version_major, version_minor))) self.assertEqual(repr(api_version), "<APIVersion: %s>" % version)

commit_message:
Add Functional Tests for exclude networks

Change-Id: Idda07743344277d119cdac46022fab05bbd2b973

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-tempest-plugin refs/changes/80/526480/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: server_with_no_nets_template = ''' heat_template_version: 2016-04-08 description: Test template to test nova server network updates. parameters: flavor: type: string image: type: string resources: net: type: OS::Neutron::Net properties: name: the_net subnet: type: OS::Neutron::Subnet properties: name: the_subnet network: {get_resource: net} cidr: 11.11.11.0/24 server: type: OS::Nova::Server properties: image: {get_param: image} flavor: {get_param: flavor} networks: [] outputs: port0_id: value: {get_attr: [server, addresses, the_net, 0, port]} port1_id: value: {get_attr: [server, addresses, the_net, 1, port]} port2_id: value: {get_attr: [server, addresses, the_net, 2, port]} port0_ip_addr: value: {get_attr: [server, addresses, the_net, 0, addr]} port1_ip_addr: value: {get_attr: [server, addresses, the_net, 1, addr]} port2_ip_addr: value: {get_attr: [server, addresses, the_net, 2, addr]} ''' self.assertEqual(['11.11.11.22'], new_networks['your_net']) class UpdateServerNetworksTest(functional_base.FunctionalTestsBase): def get_outputs(self, stack_identifier, output_key): stack = self.client.stacks.get(stack_identifier) return self._stack_output(stack, output_key) def get_parms(self): return {'flavor': self.conf.minimal_instance_type, 'image': self.conf.minimal_image_ref} def test_create_update_server_swap_network_subnet(self): '''Test updating stack with: old_snippet networks: - network: {get_resource: net} new_snippet networks: - subnet: {get_resource: subnet} ''' template = server_with_no_nets_template.replace( 'networks: []', 'networks: [{network: {get_resource: net}}]') stack_identifier = self.stack_create( template=template, stack_name='swap_network_subnet', parameters=self.get_parms()) port0 = self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id') template_update = template.replace( 'networks: [{network: {get_resource: net}}]', 'networks: [{subnet: {get_resource: subnet}}]') self.update_stack(stack_identifier, template_update, parameters=self.get_parms()) self.assertEqual(port0, self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id')) def test_create_update_server_swap_network_port(self): '''Test updating stack with: old_snippet networks: - network: {get_resource: net} new_snippet networks: - port: <the_port_created_on_stack_create> ''' template = server_with_no_nets_template.replace( 'networks: []', 'networks: [{network: {get_resource: net}}]') stack_identifier = self.stack_create( template=template, stack_name='swap_network_port', parameters=self.get_parms()) port0 = self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id') template_update = template.replace( 'networks: [{network: {get_resource: net}}]', 'networks: [{port: ' + port0 + '}]') self.update_stack(stack_identifier, template_update, parameters=self.get_parms()) self.assertEqual(port0, self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id')) def test_create_update_server_swap_subnet_network(self): '''Test updating stack with: old_snippet networks: - subnet: {get_resource: subnet} new_snippet networks: - network: {get_resource: net} ''' template = server_with_no_nets_template.replace( 'networks: []', 'networks: [{subnet: {get_resource: subnet}}]') stack_identifier = self.stack_create( template=template, stack_name='swap_subnet_network', parameters=self.get_parms()) port0 = self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id') template_update = template.replace( 'networks: [{subnet: {get_resource: subnet}}]', 'networks: [{network: {get_resource: net}}]') self.update_stack(stack_identifier, template_update, parameters=self.get_parms()) self.assertEqual(port0, self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id')) def test_create_update_server_add_subnet(self): '''Test updating stack with: old_snippet networks: - network: {get_resource: net} new_snippet networks: - network: {get_resource: net} subnet: {get_resource: subnet} ''' template = server_with_no_nets_template.replace( 'networks: []', 'networks: [{network: {get_resource: net}}]') stack_identifier = self.stack_create( template=template, stack_name='add_subnet', parameters=self.get_parms()) port0 = self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id') template_update = template.replace( 'networks: [{network: {get_resource: net}}]', ('networks: [{network: {get_resource: net}, ' 'subnet: {get_resource: subnet}}]')) self.update_stack(stack_identifier, template_update, parameters=self.get_parms()) self.assertEqual(port0, self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id')) def test_create_update_server_add_same_fixed_ip(self): '''Test updating stack with: old_snippet networks: - network: {get_resource: net} new_snippet networks: - network: {get_resource: net} fixed_ip: <the_same_ip_already_allocated> ''' template = server_with_no_nets_template.replace( 'networks: []', 'networks: [{network: {get_resource: net}}]') stack_identifier = self.stack_create( template=template, stack_name='same_fixed_ip', parameters=self.get_parms()) port0 = self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id') port0_ip_addr = self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_ip_addr') template_update = template.replace( 'networks: [{network: {get_resource: net}}]', ('networks: [{network: {get_resource: net}, ' 'fixed_ip: ' + port0_ip_addr + '}]')) self.update_stack(stack_identifier, template_update, parameters=self.get_parms()) self.assertEqual(port0, self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id')) def test_create_update_server_add_network(self): '''Test updating stack with: old_snippet networks: - subnet: {get_resource: subnet} new_snippet networks: - network: {get_resource: net} subnet: {get_resource: subnet} ''' template = server_with_no_nets_template.replace( 'networks: []', 'networks: [{subnet: {get_resource: subnet}}]') stack_identifier = self.stack_create( template=template, stack_name='add_network', parameters=self.get_parms()) port0 = self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id') template_update = template.replace( 'networks: [{subnet: {get_resource: subnet}}]', ('networks: [{network: {get_resource: net}, ' 'subnet: {get_resource: subnet}}]')) self.update_stack(stack_identifier, template_update, parameters=self.get_parms()) self.assertEqual(port0, self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id')) def test_create_update_server_multi_networks_swaps(self): '''Test updating stack with: old_snippet: networks: - network: {get_resource: net} - network: {get_resource: net} fixed_ip: 11.11.11.33 - subnet: {get_resource: subnet} new_snippet: networks: - subnet: {get_resource: subnet} - network: {get_resource: net} - network: {get_resource: net} subnet: {get_resource: subnet} ''' old_snippet = """ - network: {get_resource: net} - network: {get_resource: net} fixed_ip: 11.11.11.33 - subnet: {get_resource: subnet} """ new_snippet = """ - subnet: {get_resource: subnet} - network: {get_resource: net} - network: {get_resource: net} subnet: {get_resource: subnet} """ template = server_with_no_nets_template.replace( 'networks: []', 'networks: ' + old_snippet) stack_identifier = self.stack_create( template=template, stack_name='multi_networks_swaps', parameters=self.get_parms()) port0 = self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id') port1 = self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port1_id') port2 = self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port2_id') template_update = template.replace('networks: ' + old_snippet, 'networks: ' + new_snippet) self.update_stack(stack_identifier, template_update, parameters=self.get_parms()) self.assertEqual(port0, self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port0_id')) self.assertEqual(port1, self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port1_id')) self.assertEqual(port2, self.get_outputs(stack_identifier, 'port2_id'))

commit_message:
Add missing ilo vendor to the ilo hardware types

I'm not sure why it was missed initially. But if we don't have it,
the automatic migration to hardware types will reset the vendor
interface to no-vendor, which may look like a regression to users.

Change-Id: I6da6aa8138d7f0cbf225c15c4137edeec2c33d49
Related-Bug: #1690185

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I0bf01ba2b009dcbe4329f82c77efd6905837129d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-log-api refs/changes/47/539747/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: If1d8a32554fd6c8662adf0d83e7576cd9a3879b1

commit_message:
Clean imports in code

In some part in the code we import objects. In the Openstack style guidelines
they recommend to import only modules. [1]: "Do not import objects, only modules".

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/hacking/0.10.3/

Change-Id: I55ec09ba2977a973d384d6387958ec0972f581ec

commit_message:
Add scope_types to endpoint group policies

This commit adds scope types for all endpoint group policies. Since
endpoints are considered a system-level resource, it makes sense to
associate system scope to endpoint group policies.

From now on, a warning will be logged when a project-scoped token is
used to manage endpoint groups. Operators can opt into requiring
system-scoped tokens for these policies by enabling oslo.policy's
`enforce_scope` configuration option, which will result in an HTTP
Forbidden exception when mismatching scope is detected.

Change-Id: Icae41a1c5ce88754f0163970431a411529c3b8fe

commit_message:
add 'tags' in request body of projects

first, add 'tags' in request body of projects when create
and update.
second, put necessary parameter 'name'in first place when
create and update for convenience.

commit_message:
Add python-tripleoclient subpackage(s) from delorean-current

https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/11700  has created a new
package python-tripleoclient-container. This must be installed
from delorean-current as python-tripleoclient when deploying in
TripleO CI.

Change-Id: Ic267f6f4157abc59b64b66b7395607539bedbca9

commit_message:
Replace xml defusedxml

xml was considered as vulnerable to different atacks.
It is recommended to replace this library with defused_xml

Change-Id: I2b146dc34ada37a3ed9ecf49513d024a8ca2fb19
Related-Bug: #1625402

commit_message:
Add test case for group type specs APIs

Group type specs APIs (min_microversion is 3.11) are implemented in v3
volume group types. These APIs has not been tested in Tempest yet, and
this patch adds test case for the new features.

Including:

[1] Add group type specs APIs to v3 group_types_client
[2] Add unit tests for group type specs APIs
[3] Add test case: test_group_type_specs_create_show_update_list_delete
[4] Add release note

Change-Id: Ie7c8dd06238e111cdf691f083500018d066dd689

commit_message:
Support fabric specific Cisco FC Zone Name

This change in Fibre Channel zone manager Cisco driver allows to use the
Fibre Channel fabric level cisco_zone_name_prefix to form the zone name.
This is consistent with the "Cisco Fibre Channel Zone Driver – OpenStack
Configuration Reference”. Zone_name_prefix will fall back to the one
speficied at fc-zone-manager level if it is not specified at the more
granular FC fabric level. The existing code takes zone_name_prefix only
from the fc-zone-manager configuration.

This patch also removes the code that marks Cisco Fibre Channel Zone driver
as unsupported and deprecated. Cisco CI has been up and running again since
Jan 24, 2018. Thus the change.

This patch also contains a minor cleanup in ssh pool.

Change-Id: If629dd30ed61829a1e4a56bc2e4401ef1adef2a5

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I78e3910214f33f7422f59971e290a48f369a166a

commit_message:
ComputeDriver.update_provider_tree()

Introduce a new compute driver abstract method, update_provider_tree.

This method takes a ProviderTree object, giving the virt driver the
opportunity to update its hierarchy and inventory.

It supersedes get_inventory().

Change-Id: I3521b3b038a9df16e600083505a94da5f9790c2f
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/87/521187/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Because the input to update_provider_tree is expensive to build, drivers # should set this to True if they override that method. supports_provider_tree = False def update_provider_tree(self, provider_tree, nodename): """Update a ProviderTree object with current resource provider and inventory information. NOTE: Drivers implementing this method must set the `supports_provider_tree` class variable to True. When this method returns, provider_tree should represent the correct hierarchy of nested resource providers, as well as the inventory of those resource providers. This method supersedes get_inventory(): if this method is implemented, get_inventory() is not used. :param nova.compute.provider_tree.ProviderTree provider_tree: A ProviderTree object representing all the providers associated with the compute node's nested tree or aggregates. :param nodename: Name of the compute node for which the caller is updating providers and inventory. Drivers managing more than one node may use this in an advisory capacity to restrict changes to only the providers associated with that one node, but this is not a requirement: the caller always subsumes all changes regardless. :return: True if the provider_tree was changed; False otherwise. """ raise NotImplementedError()

subject: report client: get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-17 15:07:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/a24a5bb89dc825b37a287fe93bbecb7e799c7ad1', 'message': "WIP: Scheduler[Report]Client.get_provider_tree

SchedulerReportClient.get_provider_tree retrieves from the placement API
all providers associated with a specified provider via its nested tree
or aggregates.  It returns a fresh ProviderTree populated with these
providers and their inventory.  This is the data structure which will be
passed into the virt driver's update_provider_tree method.

A SchedulerClient.get_provider_tree wrapper is also provided.

WIP: SchedulerClient.get_provider_tree
WIP: Tests

Change-Id: I9469dec80c2b357185645ef1705f098f25dcb8c8
blueprint: nested-resource-providers

get_provider_tree itself would just return a copy of that already-built

or aggregates.  It returns a fresh ProviderTree populated with these
providers and their inventory.  This is the data structure which will be
passed into the virt driver's update_provider_tree method.

A SchedulerClient.get_provider_tree wrapper is also provided.

commit_message:
report client: get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root

SchedulerReportClient.get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root retrieves from
the placement API all providers associated with a specified provider via
its tree or aggregates.  It returns a fresh ProviderTree populated with
these providers and their inventory.  This is the data structure which
will be passed into the virt driver's update_provider_tree method.

In its current incarnation, this method will create and/or load into
cache the root provider (associated with the compute node) if not
already present.  This is because the resource tracker is currently
structured to handle init and update in the same code path.  At some
point in the future we may want to split that out and make this method
*just* return a deepcopy of the cache.

Change-Id: I9469dec80c2b357185645ef1705f098f25dcb8c8
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/98/521098/32 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_provider_tree(self, rp_uuid, rp_name): """Returns a fresh ProviderTree representing all providers which are in the same tree or in the same aggregate as the specified provider, including inventory. If no such provider exists, an empty ProviderTree is returned. :param rp_uuid: UUID of the resource provider to create the tree for. (This doesn't need to be the UUID of the root.) :param rp_name: Name of the resource provider in case we need to create a record for it in the placement API. :return: A new ProviderTree object, or None if an API error occurs. """ prov_tree = provider_tree.ProviderTree() rplist = self._get_resource_provider_tree(rp_uuid) if rplist is None: # An error occurred, and was already logged return None if not rplist: # The provider indicated by rp_uuid doesn't exist - return the # (empty) ProviderTree. return prov_tree # Seed the ProviderTree. We'll merge in aggregated RPs subsequently. prov_tree.populate_from_iterable(rplist) # Grab the aggregate UUIDs associated with all providers in the tree # TODO(efried): Implement GET /aggregates?with_members=rp_uuid[,...] so # this can be done in one call. agg_uuids = set() for rp_uuid in prov_tree.all_by_uuid(): agg_uuids |= self._get_provider_aggregates(rp_uuid) # And now grab all the providers associated with those aggregates rplist = self._get_providers_in_aggregates(*agg_uuids) if rplist is None: # An error occurred, and was already logged return None # Merge in the aggregate-associated RPs. If nonempty, this will # contain at least one of the providers already in the tree. # ProviderTree.populate_from_iterable will replace these; if anything # (e.g. generation) changed between _get_resource_provider_tree and # here, we want the latest. prov_tree.populate_from_iterable(rplist) # Now we have to populate the inventory for all the providers. for uuid, ptnode in prov_tree.all_by_uuid().items(): # TODO(efried): Handle errors here? inv_data = self._get_inventory(uuid) if inv_data: prov_tree.update_inventory(uuid, inv_data, ptnode['generation']) return prov_tree

subject: Fix bug case by none token context
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-22 04:27:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1a687417604569a7cb3066e73c781de3e381cbe6', 'message': 'Fix bug case by none token context

When set reclaim_instance_interval > 0, and then delete an
instance which booted from volume with `delete_on_termination`
set as true. After reclaim_instance_interval time pass,
all volumes boot instance will with state: attached and in-use,
but attached instances was deleted.

So add user/project CONF with admin role at cinder group,
and when determine context is_admin and without token, do
authenticaion with user/project info to call cinder api.

Change-Id: I3c35bba43fee81baebe8261f546c1424ce3a3383
Closes-Bugs: #1733736
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-11-22 06:55:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/a82cedcca9d1624e0fd0618bd7416ef52d54bc6f', 'message': 'Fix bug case by none token context

When set reclaim_instance_interval > 0, and then delete an
instance which booted from volume with `delete_on_termination`
set as true. After reclaim_instance_interval time pass,
all volumes boot instance will with state: attached and in-use,
but attached instances was deleted.

This bug case as admin context from
`nova.compute.manager._reclaim_queued_deletes` did not have
any token info, then call cinder api would be failed.

So add user/project CONF with admin role at cinder group,
and when determine context is_admin and without token, do
authenticaion with user/project info to call cinder api.

Change-Id: I3c35bba43fee81baebe8261f546c1424ce3a3383
Closes-Bugs: #1733736
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-11-23 05:37:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b603bbafcdb6838ec00c2c02270c2b47f64b70a5', 'message': 'Fix bug case by none token context

commit_message:
Fix bug case by none token context

When set reclaim_instance_interval > 0, and then delete an
instance which booted from volume with `delete_on_termination`
set as true. After reclaim_instance_interval time pass,
all volumes boot instance will with state: attached and in-use,
but attached instances was deleted.

This bug case as admin context from
`nova.compute.manager._reclaim_queued_deletes` did not have
any token info, then call cinder api would be failed.

So add user/project CONF with admin role at cinder group,
and when determine context is_admin and without token, do
authenticaion with user/project info to call cinder api.

Change-Id: I3c35bba43fee81baebe8261f546c1424ce3a3383
Closes-Bug: #1733736
Closes-Bug: #1734025
Partial-Bug: #1736773

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/23/539423/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Keystone Security Compliance ============================ Keystone has several configuration options available in order to comply with standards such as Payment Card Industry - Data Security Standard (PCI-DSS) v3.1. TripleO exposes these features via Heat parameters. They will be listed below: * ``KeystoneChangePasswordUponFirstUse``: Enabling this option requires users to change their password when the user is created, or upon administrative reset. * ``KeystoneDisableUserAccountDaysInactive``: The maximum number of days a user can go without authenticating before being considered "inactive" and automatically disabled (locked). * ``KeystoneLockoutDuration``: The number of seconds a user account will be locked when the maximum number of failed authentication attempts (as specified by ``KeystoneLockoutFailureAttempts``) is exceeded. * ``KeystoneLockoutFailureAttempts``: The maximum number of times that a user can fail to authenticate before the user account is locked for the number of seconds specified by ``KeystoneLockoutDuration``. * ``KeystoneMinimumPasswordAge``: The number of days that a password must be used before the user can change it. This prevents users from changing their passwords immediately in order to wipe out their password history and reuse an old password. * ``KeystonePasswordExpiresDays``: The number of days for which a password will be considered valid before requiring it to be changed. * ``KeystonePasswordRegex``: The regular expression used to validate password strength requirements. * ``KeystonePasswordRegexDescription``: Describe your password regular expression here in language for humans. * ``KeystoneUniqueLastPasswordCount``: This controls the number of previous user password iterations to keep in history, in order to enforce that newly created passwords are unique. .. note:: All of the aforementioned options only apply to the SQL backend. For other identity backends like LDAP, these configuration settings should be applied on that backend's side. .. note:: All of these parameters are defined as type ``string`` in heat. As per the implementation, if left unset, they will not be configured at all in the keystone configuration.

commit_message:
make ec2-api job as n-v

Due to split the neutron-tempest-plugin and
switching neutron-vpnaas to use new plugin causing
ec2-api gate is broken.

Which block the job migration to ec2-api repo
where we move the job from infra to ec2-api and
also fix the tempest plugin usage.
Both things have to go together as migrated jobs fail due to above
issue.
- I9c88ac1ecf0368c9ea7a8b20c84995ea29487184

To unblock this circular fixes, this patch makes
legacy job as n-v so that job migration patch can be merged.

Change-Id: Ic0ffe26ced252bc195ead4affa1599a953645970

commit_message:
Handle images with no data

There isn't really much we can do with these images, which glance tells
us are possible [1]. Simply raise an exception.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/python-glanceclient/latest/reference/api/glanceclient.v2.images.html

Change-Id: I5f81393a5bb41e6a674369afb899d8a41bb2c3b4
Closes-Bug: #1736759

commit_message:
Add '[Docs]' tag to bug report summary

This commit adds '[Docs]' tag to a bug report summary by default. For
openstackdocstheme, most of bugs would be documentation bugs. So, this
could be convenient for a bug reporter and also for developer who
triages bugs.

Change-Id: Ib8a02c16c426529c4fb64e390dc83e7bcbb0529a

commit_message:
Revert Cassandra version to 2 on ubuntu element

The element is configured to use version 3 of cassandra, unfortunatly
trove is actually not compatible with version 3.

Closes-Bug: #1745056
Change-Id: Ic22202eeae6f404433a84def8cf5da0e5dc28c7b

subject: Handle TZ change in iso8601 >=0.1.12
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-19 05:47:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/7bc2e1a4da295255371370584a3d57494c7a62b6', 'message': 'Handle TZ change in iso8601 >=1.12.0

The iso8601 lib introduced a change such that if running on python
3.2 or later it internally uses the python timezone information
instead of its own implementation. This does not change direct
date handling, but when converting this value there is a slight
difference where now python 2.x will show UTC times as "UTC",
but on python 3 they will end up with "UTC+00:00".

The to_primitive call for DateTime fields was doing an exact match
on "UTC" to determine whether to include "Z" in the resulting string.
This updates that handling to recognize either of the new values

commit_message:
Handle TZ change in iso8601 >=0.1.12

The iso8601 lib introduced a change such that if running on python
3.2 or later it internally uses the python timezone information
instead of its own implementation. This does not change direct
date handling, but when converting this value there is a slight
difference where now python 2.x will show UTC times as "UTC",
but on python 3 they will end up with "UTC+00:00".

The to_primitive call for DateTime fields was doing an exact match
on "UTC" to determine whether to include "Z" in the resulting string.
This updates that handling to recognize either of the new values

Change-Id: Icb29d71472932f3ddfe485298d1a5fdd08be6f12
Closes-bug: #1744160

commit_message:
Add scope_types to policy association policies

This commit associates `system` to all policy association policies.
Since policy association can be done to endpoints and services, which
are system-level resources, it makes sense to require system-scoped
tokens to make those associations.

From now on, a warning will be logged when a project-scoped token is
used to make policy associations to endpoints or services. Operators
will have the option to require system-scoped tokens for these
policies by enabling oslo.policy's `enforce_scope` configuration
option.

Change-Id: I18692cd14f9c57816da173038d7dd9ff0802246a

commit_message:
Add scope_types to project endpoint policies

This commit gives all project endpoint policies a scope type of
`system` since endpoints are system-level resources.

From now on, a warning will be logged when a project-scoped token is
used to manage project endpoint associations. Operators will have the
option to require system-scoped tokens for these policies by enabling
oslo.policy's `enforce_scope` configuration option, which will result
in an HTTP Forbidden exception when mismatching scope is detected.

Change-Id: I23b12f9a4cfbb124a6ea2cc55b5c0ccb2d463ae8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/60/526160/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Document scope_types for project policies

We have some work to do before we can actually use scope_types for
the projects resource. This commit writes those down so that we have
something to shoot for and track.

Change-Id: Id2791e1cf19a64f112c6e35725807aaf37dcdd18

commit_message:
Document fixes needed for token scope_types

Token policies are complex. In order to make sure we don't regress
we need to make sure we incorporate proper scope checks in code
before uncommenting the scope_types for token policies.

Change-Id: I9a2890688c9d3a3daf1bc872eed34d02a56d223d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/74/526174/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Token verification enforcement should be handled within keystone, but # it makes sense to have this be a system-level operation and a # project-level operation. If this API is called by a system-level # administrator, they should be able to check any token. If this API is # called by a project-level administrator, then the token should be # checked with respect to the project the administrator has a role on. # Otherwise it would be possible for administrators in one project to # validate tokens in another project, which is a security concern. This # will likely fall under a "scope" check that keystone should be # performing in code, and not making it configurable across # deployments. scope_types=['system', 'project'], scope_types=['system', 'project'], scope_types=['system', 'project'], scope_types=['system', 'project'],

commit_message:
Replace base functional tearDown with addCleanup

addCleanup will run all cleanups, even if one of them throws an
exception.

Change-Id: I0e61ea9351a361debb6a0d7d084bd7b195f8a682

commit_message:
placement: enable required traits from the flavor extra specs

This patch enables the flavor extra spec 'required:[traits]'. The
admin can specifiy a set of traits that a flavor required.

To enable this, the placement 1.17 is required, it added trait
support in the `GET /allocation_candidates` API. So bump the
minimal placement version requirement to 1.17 and update the
check in cmd `nova-status`.

Implement blueprint request-traits-in-nova

Change-Id: Ia51ace951e9a0402f873ce9751a8cd3c0283db08

the placement engine.

commit_message:
Implement get_traits() for the ironic virt driver

Implement the get_traits() method for the ironic virt driver. This
allows ironic nodes with traits set to have those traits registered
with the approriate resource provider in the placement API.

The ironic client version has been bumped to 1.37 in order to query
nodes' traits.

blueprint ironic-driver-traits

Change-Id: I4065b61edff8bfd66a163c9ccf19833316fdca8e
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/538066

subject: Fix the default value of stage_dir
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-30 08:39:08.000000000', 'files': ['roles/process-stackviz/defaults/main.yaml', 'roles/process-stackviz/README.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/b295335798d7e7dad465332aaf5456fd905982df', 'message': 'Fix the default value of stage_dir

The current default value of stage_dir does not match the valid
default from zuul-jobs, which causes stackviz to be skipped when
stage_dir is not overwritten, which is the case in all CI jobs.

Setting default and docs to "{{ ansible_user_dir }}".

Change-Id: I9fd3f8541c8e3fbc406c5e5c0c5fe8427bf74112
'}]
commit_message:
Fix the default value of stage_dir

The current default value of stage_dir does not match the valid
default from zuul-jobs, which causes stackviz to be skipped when
stage_dir is not overwritten, which is the case in all CI jobs.

Setting default and docs to "{{ ansible_user_dir }}".

Change-Id: I9fd3f8541c8e3fbc406c5e5c0c5fe8427bf74112
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/46/539146/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :default: "{{ ansible_user_dir }}"

subject: libvirt: Re-initialise volumes, encryptors, and vifs on hard reboot
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-05 16:06:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/420390eb3af9903ede33bb7bf430ff77f47837c8', 'message': 'libvirt: Re-initialise volumes, encryptors, and vifs on hard reboot

of an instance as possible before recreating it, which additionally
makes it useful to operators for attempting automated recovery of
instances in an inconsistent state.

The Libvirt driver would previously only call _destroy and
_undefine_domain when hard rebooting an instance. This would leave vifs
plugged, volumes connected, and encryptors attached on the host. It
also means that when we try to restart the instance, we assume all
these things are correctly configured. If they are not, the instance
may fail to start at all, or may be incorrectly configured when
starting.

For example, consider an instance with an encrypted volume after a
compute host reboot. When we attempt to start the instance, power_on
will call _hard_reboot. The volume will be coincidentally re-attached
as a side-effect of calling _get_guest_xml(!), but when we call
_create_domain_and_network we pass reboot=True, which tells it not to
reattach the encryptor, as it is assumed to be already attached. We
are therefore left presenting the encrypted volume data directly to
the instance without decryption.

The approach in this patch is to ensure we recreate the instance as
fully as possible during hard reboot. This means not passing
vifs_already_plugged and reboot to _create_domain_and_network, which
in turn requires that we fully destroy the instance first. This
addresses the specific problem given in the example, but also a whole
class of potential volume and vif related issues of inconsistent
state.

Because we now always tear down volumes, encryptors, and vifs, we are
relying on the tear down of these things to be idempotent.  This
highlighted that detach of the luks and cryptsetup encryptors were not
idempotent. We depend on the fixes for those os-brick drivers.
